title: Euclea racemosa
text:
Euclea racemosa (the sea guarrie or dune guarrie) is a small to medium-sized <a href="Evergreen">evergreen tree</a> that is indigenous to the <a href="Indian%20Ocean">Indian Ocean</a> coast of <a href="Africa">Africa</a> from <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a> to <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>, as well as in <a href="Comoros">Comoros</a>, <a href="Oman">Oman</a> and <a href="Yemen">Yemen</a>.
"Euclea racemosa" has leathery foliage that can be exceptionally even and dense - making it an ideal plant for hedges. A <a href="dioecious">dioecious</a> tree (male and female flowers on separate trees), it produces small white <a href="flower">flower</a>s, which are followed by red, purple and black <a href="fruit">fruit</a>s that attract <a href="bird">bird</a>s.<br>
The berries are used locally to make "Guarrie vinegar".
The name guarrie appears to derive from the local Khoe language, in which it is spelled gwarri.
